data.title: diffEditor bare theme please?
data.body:
It would be great if diffEditor supported a bare theme (using green and red) similar to the output from `git diff`. e.g.

![git-diff](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9525/28194563-63179f5c-6888-11e7-905e-5fd3081821b0.png)

data.title: Feature-request: add option "position of go to symbol"
data.body:
Now when you go to symbol or peek; your cursor position is in the **middle** of the screen:
![screenshot 12](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9638156/28193505-f9733904-6845-11e7-9b7f-d265831daa99.png)

I suggest an option to change position so that you can see **more** of a function:
![screenshot 13](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9638156/28193549-4b93ea26-6846-11e7-85a5-32052c5bdaab.png)
Something like:
`"workbench.gotoSymbol.position": "top" | "middle"`

This maybe would not be very convenient for entities other than functions. In this case option for changing position only for 
![intellisense_method_16x](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9638156/28193697-5cd4edc0-6847-11e7-93e4-521b6431396b.png) Methods, Functions and Constructors:

`"workbench.gotoSymbol.functionPosition": "top" | "middle"`

data.title: Added spacing when toggling block comments in JavaScript
data.body:
When toggling and untoggling block comments in JavaScript (I haven't tested other languages), extra spaces are added to the beginning and end of the block each time.

This did not happen in the previous version of VSCode.

- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Toggle a block comment in a section of JavaScript.
2. Untoggle it and notice the added spacing.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Support fuzzy matching of task names
data.body: Would love to type something like `task ccb` to select `gulp: clean-client-build` or something like that. Just using the same fuzzy logic as quickopen.

data.title: Fixes typo
"Rename Symbol" operations combine with the previous undo step
data.body:
When editing a JavaScript file (I haven't tested with other file types), renaming multiple symbols in a row, then attempting to undo the last one, will result in all of them being undone.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T18:24:22.120Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
gitlens|eam|4.3.1
vscode-ember|emb|0.1.0
vsc-ember-cli|fel|0.3.3
csstriggers|kis|0.3.1
cpptools|ms-|0.12.0
vscode-icons|rob|7.10.1

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new file (Cmd-N).
2. Change the language mode to JavaScript (Cmd-Shift-P, "mode", Enter, "javas", Enter).
3. Type `const foo = 1;` and press Enter.
4. Type `const bar = 2;` and press Enter.
5. Ctrl-click on the token "foo", select "Rename Symbol", type "foo1", and press Enter.
6. Ctrl-click on the token "bar", select "Rename Symbol", type "bar2", and press Enter.
7. Undo a single step (Cmd-Z).
8. Observe that both rename operations have been undone.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Git SVN plugin incorrectly reporting changes
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0-insider commit 56a5bf1724f3b882e149a3e7a24e6105a7b837c2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro - 10.0.15063 Build 15063

Steps to Reproduce:

1. git svn clone an SVN repo
2. use VSCode to make a change in the repo
3. git add
4. git commit -m "A commit message"
5. git svn dcommit

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Every file is marked as changed, even after files are committed to the git repo.
Also, changes made to the repo using VSCode are not reflected in the repo.
https://gifyu.com/image/bJiE
![bc5dada1-82fe-495e-9ca2-7e8adb6e3ca4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2086176/28191036-4984b48c-67eb-11e7-9bfb-18f7c816678e.gif)

data.title: VS code Failed to Encode Restorable State - Data Loss
data.body:
Mac OS applications should either prompt to save or, save application state so next time they run, they can restore unsaved documents.  My computer just automatically rebooted to install updates, and VSCode exited without prompting me, when it came back after reboot it only remembered one of my unsaved documents.  I just lost a significant list of important snippets that I will now have to scrub through my browser history to recover.  This is an **unacceptable** bug, if VSCode can't be trusted to encode state on exit, it should at the very least ignore the autosave flag and create a recovery version of **all** unsaved files.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T18:24:22.120Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
php-formatter|Sop|0.2.4
jsrefactor|cms|1.3.0
python|don|0.6.7
php-debug|fel|1.11.1
php-intellisense|fel|1.4.3
php-pack|fel|1.0.1
ftp-simple|hum|0.5.2
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.6

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run VSCode with autosave off
2. Create 2 unsaved documents, one significantly longer than the other
3. For good measure open some saved documents
4. Reboot the system 

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: SCM and extensions viewlet - uneven margins
data.body: From https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30250#issuecomment-314949017 The input boxes at the top of these two viewlets have much larger margins on the left than the right. The extensions box kind of lines up with the extension item text below, which maybe is the goal. In the SCM viewlet, it doesn't seem to line up with anything. Never noticed it before, but I think they would look better centered.

data.title: Contributor Tags: Add contributor assignment or help in progress
data.body:
As a contributor it would be great if there could be some way to acknowledge when
contributors pick up on an issue. There may be some time before PR is ready
and having an issue flagged as in progress from a contributor, or picked up by a team member
would allow for sorting and avoidance of duplicate work. IMHO ;-)

data.title: Add Global Undo and Redo
data.body:
It would be nice if VS Code could support global undo and redo like in Visual Studio:

>In addition to the typical undo and redo functionality that affects only individual files, the Visual Studio editor includes commands to undo or redo global actions that affect multiple files.

>Global actions include renaming a class or namespace, performing a find-and-replace operation across a solution, refactoring a database, or any other action that changes multiple files.

https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee839600(v=vs.100).aspx

Right now it's difficult to undo a search and replace or refactoring because you have to go through every file.

See also: atom/find-and-replace#331

data.title: update php grammar
data.body:
Maybe you can set up a webhook which updates the grammar after each push?


The latest updates are quite cool, because they tokenize the types inside documentation:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11234139/28181118-b42e8224-6807-11e7-9535-89a3aba8f218.png)
In this example, `string` is getting colorized, and this also contains some minor fixes.

data.title: Context menu in OPEN EDITORS pane only displays once
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: Windows 10, v1607

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file
2. Click on the file in the OPEN EDITORS pane to select it
3. Right-click to display its context menu
4. Click on `Select to compare`
5. Right-click again to display the context menu (it doesn't appear)

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

The context menu will subsequently appear on files in the FOLDER-NAME pane; but not in the OPEN EDITORS pane.

data.title: Should we clean package-lock.json files from node_modules when packaging?
data.body: xterm.js is about to introduce one (~0.5mb) and I'm sure many more modules will in the near future due to npm@5. The package-lock.json file contains a complete, quite verbose, list of dependencies, both dev and non-dev.

data.title: Extension Host hangs the CPU
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T20:36:40.018Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-83-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-markdownlint|Dav|0.9.1
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16
gitignore|cod|0.5.0
githistory|don|0.2.1
python|don|0.6.7
cpptools|ms-|0.12.0
csharp|ms-|1.11.0
latex|ms-|0.1.3
vscode-hexdump|sle|1.4.0
cmake|twx|0.0.17
cmake-tools|vec|0.10.1
vscode-arduino|vsc|0.2.4

(2 theme extensions excluded)

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start code normally with all extensions
Effect: after startup and extension load extension host loads the CPU up to 100% and fails to stop even after exiting vscode. The process causing this is under linux:
/usr/share/code/code /usr/share/code/resources/app/out/bootstrap --type=extensionHost
2. To verify this one can check htop - the process above will always be on top.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

Please fix this issue, before the June release Code was a dream.

data.title: Make splited editors (panes) like vim or tmux.
data.body:
- Let's to think about removing LEFT/CENTER/RIGHT (or TOP/CENTER/BOTTOM) separation.
- Instead of it we could have just one shared tabs bar and as many as you want panes.
- Click on some tab just loads a corresponding file into current pane.
- It will be cool to resize and move this panes as you wish.
- We could also to attach hotkeys for speedy pane movements.

After all, the pane-based interface has long proved its usefulness.
See for example to vim/tmux/i3wm user expirience.

- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: Xubuntu 16.04

data.title: Add ability to group tasks in tasks.json so common parameters can be shared

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: Windows 7 Professsional

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create task.
2. Create another task with similar configuration. Have to repeat all the configuration parameters such as:
"type": "shell",
"problemMatcher": [],
"presentation": {
        "echo": true,
        "reveal": "always",
        "focus": false,
        "panel": "dedicated"
      },
      "options": {
        "cwd": "${fileDirname}"
      },
      "command": "",
The only thing is different could be the "args", so why have to repeat everything. If tasks could be grouped they could share/inherit the same parameters. They could add or override the shared parameters, This would make it easier to create multiple tasks (e.g. build tasks for different build configurations).

BTW: The Help, Report Issues menu entry has stopped filling in the VS Code, OS, extensions in the new issues window. Just tried to again and the details were filled in. May be an intermittent problem or a mistake on my part.

}

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Run any Task, e.g. npm: run start
2.In the terminal see:
> Executing task: npm run start <


Usage: npm <command>

where <command> is one of:
    access, adduser, bin, bugs, c, cache, completion, config,
    ddp, dedupe, deprecate, dist-tag, docs, doctor, edit,
    explore, get, help, help-search, i, init, install,
    install-test, it, link, list, ln, login, logout, ls,
    outdated, owner, pack, ping, prefix, prune, publish, rb,
    rebuild, repo, restart, root, run, run-script, s, se,
    search, set, shrinkwrap, star, stars, start, stop, t, team,
    test, tst, un, uninstall, unpublish, unstar, up, update, v,
    version, view, whoami

npm <cmd> -h     quick help on <cmd>
npm -l           display full usage info
npm help <term>  search for help on <term>
npm help npm     involved overview

Specify configs in the ini-formatted file:
    C:\Users\Nuke\.npmrc
or on the command line via: npm <command> --key value
Config info can be viewed via: npm help config

npm@4.2.0 C:\Users\Nuke\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\npm

Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it.



<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Improve xterm.js types
No import autocomplete with Typescript
data.body:
In new release, there's no path autocomplete on modules like it used to be on September 2016 release.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a Typescript project with `"baseUrl": "./"` in compiler options
2. Create some basic module
3. Try `import Foo from "folder/module"`. There's no autocomplete

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No
